Cross a J.T. Miller b V. Danghyan a A.S. Mukasyan a E.E. Wolf a ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Notre Dame IN 46556 United States b Davidson School of Chemical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States Davidson School of Chemical Engineering Purdue University West Lafayette IN 47907 United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract We report on the high activity and stability towards deactivation during ethanol decomposition of mono (Ni, Cu) and bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts supported on ceria and silica that were prepared by impregnated support solution combustion synthesis (ISCS). Ni supported on ceria, behaves much like bulk Ni, as it deactivates within a few hours of time on stream (TOS). Addition of Cu improves the stability of ceria supported Ni-Cu bimetallic catalysts but it still deactivates during 10 h of TOS. Ni prepared by dry impregnation on silica deactivates completely during a few h of TOS. Ni supported on silica prepared by ISCS, show a remarkable high stability for over 30 h TOS and Ni-Cu is stable over 100 h of TOS operating at 100% conversion. XRD, XPS, HRTEM, in-situ XAS and textural characterization of these catalysts show that the surface Ni concentration is small on silica-supported catalysts due to partial encapsulation of Ni by the silica support, which protects the metal particles from carbon formation, thus hindering deactivation. Addition of Cu to silica increases the number of active sites, but also decreases CO chemisorption on Ni indicating the formation of a Cu-Ni alloy, which had been reported to inhibit carbon formation on Ni. The combined effect of encapsulation and formation of Ni-Cu surface alloys result in the remarkable stability of the Cu-Ni silica supported catalyst. Keywords Supported catalysts Combustion synthesis Ni-Cu catalysts Hydrogen production 1 Introduction The future use of fuel cells depends on hydrogen availability and storage, as well as transportation challenges and safety issues associated with using hydrogen. One alternative solution to overcome these problems is to use liquid hydrocarbons, such as ethanol, for on-board hydrogen production. Ethanol is non-toxic, easily transported through the current infrastructure, has a high volumetric energy density and in addition is carbon neutral since is a biofuel. There have been many studies using various reactions of ethanol for hydrogen generation, including decomposition [1–3], steam reforming [4–16], oxidation [4,6], and oxidative steam reforming [12]. In this work we studied ethanol decomposition (C2H5OH → H2 + CH4 + CO) due to its simplicity and lack of competing side reactions. We selected Ni and Ni-Cu catalysts because they are known to be active for ethanol decomposition, but exhibit a propensity to deactivate due to carbon formation, sintering of the active metal, and oxidation of the Ni surface. Oxidation of the catalyst can be avoided by using the ethanol decomposition reaction and hence carbon formation remains a limiting factor for their use during long time on stream (TOS). Various studies reports results of improved activity and stability of Ni and other transition metals catalysts. These include using promoters [15,16], adding oxygen or steam to the feed stream [4,7–9], changing the active metal precursors/preparation methods [10–12,18], dispersing the active metal onto various supports [5,8,16,17,19], such as ceria [8,11,14,20,21] or on supports exhibiting strong metal-support interactions, and encapsulating the active particles [10,18,22,23]. Based on our previous studies with unsupported Ni, Cu and Fe catalysts using solution combustion synthesis (SCS) [1,2,24–26] in this work we addressed the effect of supporting Ni and Ni-Cu catalysts on CeO2, and SiO2, which have different surface areas, and study their activity and stability during ethanol decomposition. The focus of this work is to prepare supported monometallic and bimetallic nickel and copper supported catalysts using a modification of SCS referred hereafter as impregnated support combustion synthesis (ISCS) [2,26]. The activity-selectivity was measured vs temperature and time on stream at 250 °C. TEM and XPS studies were conducted before and after the reaction. In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to determine the composition and structure of the catalysts after reduction and under reaction conditions. The novelty of the work is the finding that impregnating Ni and Cu on the silica followed by SCS resulted in a significant improvement in the catalysts stability and lifetime compared with a standard dry impregnation preparation. The multi-characterization techniques used indicated that the combined effect of encapsulation and formation of Ni-Cu surface alloys result in the remarkable stability of the Cu-Ni silica supported catalyst. 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 Catalyst preparation ISCS Details of the SCS preparation of unsupported catalysts had been described [1], so only a brief summary is presented here. Basically the reactive solution, which is a mixture of a nitrate metal precursor or oxidant and an organic fuel, such as glycine or urea, are heated until the combustion reaction ignites, self-propagating through the media. The reaction stoichiometry, described by Eq. (1), shows that depending on the fuel/oxidizer ratio= φ, the reactants can form metal oxides (and in the case of large φ, can form metals [1]) and various gases: (1) M e ν N O 3 ν s + 5 9 ν φ N H 2 C H 2 C O O H s + 5 4 ν φ - 1 O 2 g → M e O ν 2 s + 10 9 ν φ C O 2 g + 25 18 ν φ H 2 O ( g ) + 5 φ + 9 18 ν N 2 ( g ) In this work we prepared the reactive solutions to be combusted, by dissolving nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Alfa Aesar, 98%), copper nitrate trihydrate (Alfa Aesar, 98%), and glycine (Alfa Aesar, 98.5%) in deionized water with a fuel to oxidizer stoichiometric ratio, ϕ of 1.75 [2]. In the ISCS preparation, the reactive solutions were impregnated by incipient wetness on cerium (IV) oxide (Aldrich, 99.95%) or silicon dioxide (Aldrich, 99.8%) supports to produce 10 wt.% of Ni, 10 wt.% Cu and 10/10 wt.% Ni/Cu on these supports. The impregnated powders were placed, and compacted in aluminum foil boats and left to dry overnight at room temperature. The ceria supported catalysts were ignited at one end of the boat, creating a combustion front that propagated throughout the sample without any additional heat source. Due to its different thermal properties, the boat with the high area silica supported powders, were placed on a hot plate and heated uniformly to start the CS reaction, which propagated vertically [2,26]. The resulting catalysts powders are referred hereafter as Ni/SiO2-CS Ni/CeOx, Cu/SiO2-CS, Cu/CeOx-CS, NiCu/SiO2-CS and NiCu/CeOx-CS. We also prepared silica supported catalysts by dry impregnation i.e. using Ni(NO3)2 without glycine, identified by a suffix I after the catalyst’s name. 2.2 Catalyst activity, selectivity, and TOS evaluation Catalytic activity was measured in a continuous flow fixed bed quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure as previously described [24–28]. The catalyst powders were grounded into a fine powder using a pestle and mortar, which was then pressed into a wafer at 10,000 psi. The resulting wafer was then broken into small particles and sieved to select those having 0.6–1 mm in size to eliminate diffusion limitations. 0.4 g of the catalyst was placed in the reactor and reduced with hydrogen at 300 °C for 1 h. After reduction, the reactor was purged with nitrogen flow (50 cc/min) and cooled to room temperature (RT) for 3 h. The nitrogen flow was then redirected through a bubbler filled with ethanol and into the reactor. The reactor temperature was raised in steps up to 400 °C. The composition of the reactor effluent was measured using two gas chromatographs connected in parallel using a 3.7 m HAYESEP Q column, and a 1.8 m molecular sieve 5 Å and a 5.0 m HAYESEP D [1,2]. Conversion and effluent mole fractions were calculated as described in Eqs. (2) and (3), respectively, where ni are the moles of species i . The mass balances closed within 5–7% (2) X E t O H = n E t O H , i n - n E t O H , o u t n E t O H , i n × 100 (3) χ i = n i ∑ n i × 100 2.3 Catalyst characterization The fresh commercial supports were characterized by scanning and transmission electron microscopy (SEM, TEM). A Magellan 400 (FEI, USA) field emission SEM operating at 10 kV was used to image the un-impregnated commercial supports at 300,000× magnification. The metal supported particles were imaged using a FEI Titan 80-300 TEM with a point-to-point resolution of 0.19 nm with information limit below 0.1 nm. Bulk crystal structure was determined by XRD (Bruker-D8 Advance DaVinci), using a Cu Kα mono-chromatic radiation (1.54 Å= λ) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA, over a range of 2θ from 0 to 100°. Textural characterization such as surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the support and pre-dried catalysts were measured after being vacuum degassed for 15 h at 373 K in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 adsorption instrument. The Ni surface area and dispersion were determined in the same instrument by CO chemisorption. Samples were first pretreated in-situ in hydrogen flow at 400 °C for 90 min. After cooling to 35 °C, CO chemisorption was performed at that temperature at CO pressures between 100 and 350 mbar. Dispersion was calculated from CO chemisorption assuming crystallites have hemispherical shape and a 1:1 stoichiometry of adsorbed CO per surface Ni atom. The chemisorption results were first tested on a standard sample provided by Micromeritics and the dispersion results agreed with a few %. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out in a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 instrument, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), using pure hydrogen flow of 10 mL/min. 25 mg of the sample was placed in a quartz U-tube and pretreated in Ar at 200 °C for 1 h and then the temperature ramped at 5 °C/min to 750 °C under H2. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the previously reduced catalysts powders were obtained on a PHI Versa-Probe II spectrometer, using Al Kα radiation at 1486.6 eV under high power mode. Care was taken to minimize exposure to air while transferring the samples into the XPS equipment to avoid surface oxidation, and the powders were sputtered with Ar for a few minutes to clean the surface prior to analysis. A Multipak software package was used to deconvolute the spectral peaks and determine relative elemental surface concentrations by comparing areas under the deconvoluted curves, each corresponding to different oxidation states of Ni and Cu (correcting for different elements using relative sensitivity factors). XAS experiments were conducted at the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) in sector 10, Materials Research Collaborative Access Team (MRCAT). Details of these experiments have been described in detail in a previous paper [25] with unsupported catalysts so only a brief summary is presented here. The catalysts powders were loaded in a 2.5” cylindrical holder with six 4 mm channels in an annular geometry and with an empty channel at the center. The holder was placed in a quartz tube fitted with polyimide film on either end to allow the X-ray beam to run through the catalysts in transmission mode. The tube, fitted with a gas inlet and outlet to allow gas (hydrogen and ethanol) flow over the catalysts, was placed in a split oven that could be operated at temperatures up to 400 °C. Ceria absorbs much of the beam, resulting in lower signals and noisy data so all ceria supported samples were run in fluorescence mode using a special detector perpendicular to the tube and beamline. The catalysts were first pre-reduced outside the X-ray beamline for 2 h under 5% hydrogen flow at 300 °C. After cooling to room temperature in He, the tube was transferred in He to the beam line, and the catalysts were reduced again for approximately 30 min., The gas lines and the catalysts were then purged with helium, that was then sent through a bubbler filled with ethanol and then to the tube. To get spectra on the different channels the tube was adjusted to be in line with the beam Spectra for both nickel and copper were taken during reduction at 300°C, at room temperature, and under ethanol at 100, 200, and 300 °C. WinXAS and Athena software programs were used to analyze XAS spectra. The EXAFS portion of the results was fitted to a scattering model, which gave us an estimate of the measured bond lengths between atoms and the number of nearest neighbors. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characterization of supports and metal dispersion The textural structure of the fresh commercial supports were first characterized by SEM, as shown in Fig. 1 . Ceria appears as large rectangular particles ranging from 15 to 100 nm in size (Fig. 1a), while the silica support (Fig. 1b) consists of much smaller semi spherical particles of approximately 10 nm in size. The BET specific surface area of the fresh supports along RE with the specific surface areas of the supported Ni, Ni-Cu, and Cu catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The BET area of the fresh silica support is 186 m2/g, whereas the fresh ceria support exhibits a much lower surface area (17 m2/g) in agreement with the SEM micrographs After impregnating the precursors onto the supports and using CS to obtain the metal or metal oxide supported onto them, the surface area of the support decreases by 25% on NiCu/SiO2-CS and 30% on NiCu/CeOx-CS, compared to the non-impregnated supports. This relative small decrease in surface area of the supported catalyst after CS is due to the short time of exposure (seconds) to the high combustion temperatures that does not allow for significant sintering of the support and the metal particles. XRD results of the supported Ni, Cu and Cu on both supports (Fig. S1) agree with the textural results, showing very sharp lines for ceria (at 2θ of 28.5, 33.1, 47.5, 56.3, 59.1, 69.4, 76.7, 79.1, 88.4, and 95.4 °) indicating high degree of crystallinity, and broad lines forming wide peaks for quasi amorphous silica. The XRD patterns also show small broad peaks for nickel oxide (at 2θ: 37.2, 43.3, and 62.9) and copper oxide (at 2θ: 35.5, 38.7, 48.7, and 61.5) on the silica supported catalysts, indicating the presence of small, well-dispersed Ni and Cu oxides crystallites. It should be noted that while the value of ϕ used should have produced metal crystallites in unsupported catalysts [28], using time resolved XRD we found that in supported silica catalysts, the small Ni metal crystallites initially produced, oxidize readily upon exposure to air [24]. Due to the high intensity of the ceria peaks, the NiO and CuO lines are not observed above the background noise. TEM images of the fresh silica and ceria supports (Fig. 2 a,b) and the 10% Ni supported catalysts (Fig. 2c,d) show highly dispersed 2 nm Ni oxide particles over the ceria and silica supports. Although it was difficult to detect the small NiO crystallites by XRD (Fig. S1). Electron diffraction patterns collected during TEM analysis (not shown), confirms the existence of crystalline NiO. Fig. 2c, shows Ni oxide crystallites deposited atop the ceria particles, while Ni oxide on silica appears to be partially covered by the silica support. This is an important result and will be discussed in depth later. Fig. 3 shows images of NiO supported on ceria and silica through dark field STEM imaging. It is difficult to distinguish NiO on ceria in STEM mode as they have close atomic number, so the smaller NiO crystallites are not clearly contrasted on ceria (Fig. 3a). Highly dispersed NiO crystallites on silica (Fig. 3b) are much more easily observed due to the large atomic weight difference. The light colored NiO crystallites are seen highly dispersed on the silica grains. 3.2 CO chemisorption Table 2 shows the chemisorption results of the reduced catalysts showing that dispersion is quite high on silica and much lower on ceria. Addition of Cu, which does not adsorb CO, decreases the amount of CO adsorbed in both supports resulting in a lower estimate for Ni dispersion. This indicates that Cu could be covering Ni crystallites decreasing CO adsorption, probably via formation of a surface Cu-Ni alloy that would inhibits CO chemisorption. Dispersion values on supported Ni catalysts in the literature range from 4 to 11% on 5% Ni/SiO2 [16] to 15–30% on 10%Ni/SiO2 [30] depending on the preparation method used. 10% Ni on ceria has been reported to have Ni dispersions of 15–24% [29,31]. The results in Table 2 show that Ni dispersion on ISCS prepared catalysts is high on the silica support whereas on Cu-Ni are within the literature values. On ceria Ni dispersion is lower because of its smaller BET area, which will cause multiple layer deposition and agglomeration of the Ni crystallites. It should be emphasized that in the case of Ni-Cu supported catalysts, in general, there should be a distribution of crystallites sizes and compositions, ranging from Ni only, Cu only and Cu-Ni alloys. While ISCS produces small crystallites they are not of a single size and composition. CO characterization measurements, gives an average value of the contribution of all the different sites and we can only assume that the average value obtained is from the contribution of Ni, Cu and Cu-Ni sites. 3.3 TPR characterization Fig. 4 shows TPR results on Ni/SiO2-CS and Ni/CeOx-CS catalysts carried out to determine the extent of reduction of these catalysts. On Ni/CeOx-CS the TPR signal shows peaks at 195 °C, 275 °C, 325 °C and a shoulder at 415 °C, whereas on the Ni/SiO2-CS catalyst the peaks are located at 195 °C, 310 °C with a broad peak at 535 °C. More important is that the Ni/CeOx-CS has a larger area under the curve, even though it has lower dispersion, this would indicate that a greater bulk percent reduction of this sample compared to Ni/SiO2-CS. Alternatively, this difference in reducibility can be interpreted as NiO being less accessible to the reducing gas indicating that it they might be encapsulated within the silica support. In both catalysts, there is a slight shoulder (greater in the ceria sample) around 200 °C which has been reported to be due to reduction of Ni (III) to Ni (II) [32]. The large peaks around 330 °C correspond to Ni (II) reduction to metallic Ni, which has been shown to reduce from 300 to 400 °C. Barrault et al. [33] demonstrated that the reduction temperature of Ni (II) depends on the support used, as Ni on silica is reduced at ˜500 °C, while on ceria it is reduced at much lower temperatures around 400 °C. The difference in reduction temperature between the two supports in Fig. 4 is less than 50 °C. On ceria, the two close peaks at 275 °C and 325 °C have been attributed by Wang et al. [34] to the reduction of interfacial oxygen ions of Ni oxide interacting with the surface oxygen vacancies of the support, and the reduction of highly dispersed Ni oxide species, respectively. Ni/CeOx-CS has another shoulder around 415 °C, which correlates with the partial reduction of surface ceria. Ni/SiO2-CS does not show this shoulder, instead it exhibits a small reduction peak at 535 °C, corresponding to Ni species strongly bonded to the support surface species as reported by Mile et al. [32]. It is not likely that this peak is from a contribution of Ni silicates as they reduce at a higher temperature of 662 °C [35], and there was no evidence of these compounds in the XPS spectra. Thus this peak, as well as the small reduction area of Ni/SiO2-CS can be attributed to he reduction of encapsulated Ni in silica occurring at temperatures higher than what we used for reducing the catalysts. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Nickel near surface concentrations obtained from the Ni 2p3/2 XPS signal on ceria and silica are reported in Table 3 . The surface Ni concentration on Ni/CeOx-CS is 25%, while on Ni/SiO2-CS is only 2%. Since there is a significant difference between the BET surface areas of silica and ceria, with the same metal loading of 10% on each support, the surface concentration of Ni on ceria should be an order magnitude larger than on silica, as confirmed by the XPS results. If the TEM images of the NiO crystallites (Fig. 2c) correspond with images of reduced Ni crystallites, they appear as sitting atop the surface of ceria. On Ni/SiO2-CS, crystallites appear to be embedded in or partially encapsulated by the silica support (Fig. 2d), in agreement with its lower surface concentration from XPS. Table 3 also shows that cerium concentration dominates the surface on Ni/CeOx-CS at 59%, with a small percentage of oxygen (9%), while on Ni/SiO2-CS the oxygen signal dominates at 66%. Therefore the surface of CeOx appears to be oxygen deficient, while the opposite is true for silica, which can be due to the size difference between Ce and Si relative to oxygen. When comparing XPS signals on supported catalysts one should take into account that the photoelectrons reaching the detector are emitted from atoms from the top surface layer of the particles and not from atoms on crystallites residing in the internal pores of the support. This agrees with the observation of the larger Ni surface signal on ceria since is less porous than silica. 3.5 Activity, selectivity and stability results Ethanol conversion vs temperature results were obtained for all of the supported catalysts and are displayed in Fig. 5 . Depending on temperature, NiCu/CeOx-CS has the highest ethanol conversion of all metals on ceria, followed by Ni/CeOx-CS and Cu/CeOx-CS (Fig. 5a). NiCu/SiO2-CS has similar conversion compared to Ni/SiO2-CS, and both are more active than Cu/SiO2-CS (Fig. 5b). At 200 °C, Ni/CeOx-CS exhibits only 75% ethanol conversion, while over Ni/SiO2-CS conversion reaches 95%. It should be noted that in these experiments at a given temperature, the time on stream (TOS) was short (30 min), so no noticeable deactivation was observed. The Cu supported catalyst are also active and since 10% Cu was added to the 10% Ni supported catalysts the bimetallic catalysts have twice the combined Ni + Cu metal concentration than the monometallic catalysts. However as shown below the selectivity for H2 production of Cu and Ni is quite different. Mole fractions of the product effluent streams for each of these catalysts are displayed in Fig. 6 , showing trends similar to those reported in the literature [12]. Nickel is able to break the CC bond of ethanol at temperatures above 150 °C to produce CH4, CO, and H2 (Fig. 6a), while copper cannot do so, yielding CH3CHO and H2 (Fig. 6b). The Ni, Cu and NiCu selectivity trends are similar on the silica and ceria supported samples. Therefore the difference in the performance between the ceria and silica supported catalysts is due to the effect of the dispersion of Ni, Cu and Ni-Cu on each support. To determine the catalyst stability towards deactivation, ethanol decomposition was studied at 250 °C on the most active Ni, Cu and bimetallic catalysts for an extended period of time on stream (TOS). Fig. 7 shows that a 10% Ni on SiO2 catalyst prepared by standard dry impregnation techniques (Ni/SiO2-I) deactivates completely in less than 5 h. Ni/CeOx-CS deactivated very quickly, at a rate comparable to unsupported nickel catalysts prepared by SCS. The addition of copper to Ni on CeOx (NiCu/CeOx-CS) enhanced slightly the stability, possibly due to the formation of a Ni-Cu alloy, as reported by Fierro et al. [29]. Cerium oxides are known to have a high oxygen storage capacity, which can oxidize the active surface of carbon residues to CO2, making it more active and stable than the same active metal on an inert support [3]. This effect was not observed in this work, because without addition of oxygen to the feed, carbon residues are not oxidized. Frusteri et al. [11] reported that carbon formation is promoted by the strong interaction between the ceria particles and absorbed reaction intermediates species. This contributed to the higher rate of deactivation found on the Ni/CeOx-CS catalyst. The most notable results shown in Fig. 7 is the increased stability of the Ni/SO2-CS and NiCu/SiO2-CS catalysts, the latter showing a nearly constant 100% conversion after 100 h of TOS!. It should be noted that while the mol fraction decreased with deactivation, the selectivity, that is the ratio with respect to the feed ethanol mol fraction, remained constant with TOS, at their initial values shown in Fig. 6 at 250 °C. Based on the characterization results reported in Sections 3.1–3.4, we hypothesized that the active sites on Ni/SiO2-CS are protected from deactivation for 30 h through partial encapsulation of the Ni preventing carbon formation, and did not fully deactivated until 75 h TOS. The Ni-Cu/SiO2-CS catalyst stay active at 100% conversion for over 100 h TOS by the combined effect of having more sites by the addition of 10% Cu, i.e. doubling the active sites, the possible formation of a surface Ni-Cu alloy, and encapsulation of both Ni and Cu sites. On ceria, encapsulation does not occur leading to rapid deactivation, therefore addition of Cu does not increase the stability to deactivation as in silica. In-situ characterization by XAS were carried out to further clarify this point. 3.6 In situ XAS XAS We first obtained Ni XANES results at various times during reduction in 5% hydrogen/He at 300 °C (Fig. 8 ) over the freshly prepared Ni/CeOx-CS, NiCu/CeOx-CS, and Ni/SiO2-CS. The Ni K-edge XANES spectra of Ni/SiO2-CS and Ni/CeO2-CS after reduction at 300 °C are shown in Fig. 8a. The metallic fraction is calculated based on a linear interpolation of the XANES edges height of the NiO (pink line) and metallic Ni foil (black line) used as references for 100% oxidized and metallic Ni respectively [36]. The XANES Ni oxidation state during reduction at 300 °C agrees with TPR results showing that Ni/SiO2-CS (blue line-Fig. 8a) it is only reduced to ˜35% metallic Ni, as estimated from the XANES results (Fig. 8b). Ni is reduced ˜65% to metallic Ni on CeOx (red line-Fig. 8a) and is reduced to 85% metallic Ni on the Ni-Cu bimetallic catalyst. Copper is more easily reduced than Ni and it increases the extent of Ni reduction probably through formation of Ni-Cu alloy, consistent with the XANES results. It should be noted that these results were obtained with diluted H2 whereas for TPR and pretreatment pure hydrogen was used. In situ EXAFS spectra (see Fig. S3) on Ni/CeOx-CS, NiCu/CeOx-CS, and Ni/SiO2-CS in hydrogen at 300 °C were fitted to a scattering model. The results in terms of particle sizes (7–8 nm) and Ni-Ni bond distances (2.48 Å) along with the best fitting parameters are summarized in Table 4 . The Ni-Ni coordination number from the fit was divided by the fraction of metallic Ni obtained in the XANES results. This modified Ni-Ni coordination number was then used estimate the size of the crystallite for FCC metals [36]. The crystallite sizes obtained from these results, while in a similar range as those calculated from CO chemisorption, do not reflect the differences in sizes on the ceria and silica supports. The model used to fit the EXAFS results is based on crystal of uniform size and it gives an average value that does not reflect the differences in the size distribution on the different supports. Table 4 also show an increase in the percent of reduced nickel with the addition of copper, which contributes to the increased activity as determined from Fig. 5. Both XAS results (XANES and EXAFS) shows that Ni on ceria is 65% reduced while on silica is only reduced to ˜ 35–38%. After reduction and under ethanol flow at 300 °C (not shown), the % of metallic Ni increases to 90% on Ni/CeOx-CS and to 65% on Ni/SiO2-CS [27]. Under either gas environment, the % of Ni reduced in silica is less than on ceria indicating that some of the Ni is not as accessible to the reactants as on ceria by being partially embedded or constrained by the silica support. All the characterization results presented so far indicate that impregnating the silica support followed by CS produces Ni crystallites that are more intimately mixed with the support unlike the standard impregnation followed by reduction. Tomiyama et al. [37] also report that by using a sol-gel process, nickel particles become entrapped in the network of silica, decreasing carbon formation and improving stability towards deactivation. Wang et al. [34] reported hydrogen generation from ethanol steam reforming, using various catalysts prepared by the urea-nitrate process (similar to CS but using urea as the fuel). These authors found that the most active catalyst (Ni/MgO) had the lowest surface concentration of Ni (Ni/Mg = 0.01) out of several catalysts (Ni/ZnO: Ni/Zn = 0.03 and Ni/Al2O3: Ni/Al = 0.04). Thus the lower reducibility of Ni on silica prepared by CS is consistent with a structure in which some Ni crystallites are partially entrapped or encapsulated by the silica support, which constrain Ni and hinders carbon formation resulting in an increase in stability towards deactivation. To further understand the cause of the enhanced resistance to deactivation we studied carbon formation by XPS at different TOS. 3.7 Carbon formation XPS C1s, Ni 2p3/2, Si 2p, and Ce 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spectra of the fresh and spent Ni/SiO2-CS, Ni/CeOx-CS, and NiCu/CeOx-CS catalysts were obtained to determine changes in surface concentration after extended TOS. The C1s spectrum of the fresh and spent Ni/SiO2-CS, Ni/CeOx-CS, and NiCu/CeOx-CS catalysts are reported in Fig. 9 . Surface carbon increases after TOS in all catalysts correlating with increasing rate of deactivation (note different signals intensities in each figure). Table 5 shows the % change in total elemental surface composition and relative changes in binding energy (BE), representing different oxidation states at different TOS. Ni/CeOx-CS deactivates to 20% ethanol conversion in ˜5 h (Fig. 7), and exhibits a 100% increase of surface carbon along with a large decrease in surface Ni concentration of 59%, with a decrease of 32% of Ce surface concentration (Table 5). These results indicates that carbon covers preferentially the Ni crystallites decreasing the number of active sites and hence the activity of Ni/CeOx-CS. Furthermore, a new carbon related peak (283.4 eV) corresponding to carbide formation [35] appears after 5 h of reaction on Ni/CeOx-CS. This new peak has been attributed to the formation of Ni3C on the surface, and it was also observed in our previous studies of the same reaction in unsupported Ni [25], presumably related to deactivation in the unsupported catalysts. Due to the low reaction temperature used, no carbon filament or nanotubes were detected in our results [12], but the deposited carbon can still form carbide moeties. A carbide peak is not detected in the NiCu/CeOx-CS catalyst, as a Ni-Cu alloy could also inhibits carbide formation, so that after the same TOS it exhibits 70% ethanol conversion compared to 20% on Ni/CeOx-CS. The NiCu/CeOx-CS catalyst shows a 49% increase of surface carbon deposition after reaction, with a decrease of 36% Ni surface reduction. Therefore, with the addition of Cu, the rate of carbon formation over Ni based catalysts is somewhat decreased although not completely inhibited. Ni/SiO2-CS showed no deactivation after 1 day of reaction (Fig. 7) and exhibits only a small decrease in surface Ni (10%) and C (24%) relative to the fresh catalyst (Table 5). The decrease in carbon after 24 h of TOS could be due to the removal of residual carbon from glycine decomposition left after CS upon exposure of product gases. After 3 days of TOS and complete deactivation of the Ni/SiO2–CS catalyst, there is a 100% increase of surface C and a 32% decrease in Ni surface concentration. On the other hand, NiCu/SiO2-CS after 3 days of TOS running at 100% conversion, exhibits a 185% increase in surface C relative to the fresh catalyst, but a decrease of only 19% surface Ni after reaction. This large increase in C is due to the higher number of active sites upon addition of Cu and because at high conversion the bimetallic catalysts was producing intermediates that form both the products as well as carbon precursors. The monometallic Ni/SiO2-CS catalyst is completely deactivated after 3 days of TOS, resulting in less carbon laydown. TEM images of spent Ni/CeOx-CS and Ni/SiO2-CS catalysts, Fig. 10 , show no sign of carbon filaments or nanotubes formation but an amorphous layer of carbon covering the surface of the Ni particles on the spent catalysts. On Ni/CeOx-CS carbon appears to completely cover all of the Ni particles after reaction compared to before reaction (Fig. 10a), agreeing with XPS C1s results. Ni crystallites on Ni/SiO2-CS images appear relatively fuzzy in Fig. 10c and d, in agreement with the hypothesis that thus is due to their partial encapsulation of Ni by the silica support after CS. It was difficult to capture a TEM image of the carbon layer on the silica, but there it’s a faint layer of C formation surrounding the Ni particles after 3 days of reaction (Fig. 10d). Partial encapsulation of the Ni, Cu and Ni-Cu crystallites that exhibits high activity requires that the surrounding silica exhibits some surface porosity to allow the reactants and hydrogen to reach the active surface. Other preparative techniques have been reported to achieve similar results. Li et al. [38] used multiple steps to coat Ni with a porous silica layer using a shell deposition procedure to prepare a catalyst for syngas production stable for 500 min TOS. Pt nanoparticles dispersed on silica beads were covered with a fresh layer of mesoporous silica to increase its stability towards sintering of Pt particles [39], however, the resulting materials had to be etched after the mesoporous silica coating to allow the reactants to reach the active surface. Stair and coworkers [40,41], used Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) of an alumina layer that can be tuned in size to partially cover active Pd particles and prevent sintering of those particles at the higher reaction temperatures required to reach conversions to values comparable to catalysts with no over-coating layers [40]. This group also reported an increase in ethylene yield during oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane over the same catalysts with less than 6% of the carbon formation found on non-coated catalysts [41]. The over-coated catalysts are initially not active for the reaction due to the complete encapsulation of the active metal particles by the alumina over-coat layer, but become active only after high temperature treatments (700 °C calcination), that creates porosity allowing reactant gases to reach the metal nanoparticles. These authors also hypothesized that the overcoat layer could divide the active Pd particles into small ensembles that do not allow carbon growth as proposed much earlier by Biloen et al. [42]. Similarly, the ISCS preparation on silica reported in this work produced highly active catalysts presumably with partially encapsulated Ni particles but with enough microporosity that allows the reactants molecules to reach the surface of the active metal but hinders carbon formation and decreases deactivation. Our ISCS prepared catalysts, however, did not require additional high temperature calcination or reduction procedures, or etching of the encapsulated particles. Fig. 11 , shows in-situ FTIR transmission spectra of CO adsorbed on Ni/CeOx-CS and Ni/SiO2-CS, the former exhibiting a major broad band at 2191 cm−1 with a shoulder at about 2182 cm−1, and the latter a sharper band at about 2190 cm−1 with no shoulder. We did not find reports of adsorbed CO IR bands that matched the location of the ones observed in the Ni/SiO2-CS catalyst. We assume that the main peak corresponds to the CO adsorbed on the face of the Ni crystallites, while the shoulder can be due to CO adsorbed on the step and edges. Lu et al. [40,41] suggested that the edges can be the initial point of carbon deposition. Thus, the larger shoulder on Ni/CeOx-CS seen in Fig. 11, would correspond to a greater number of Ni edge active sites when compared to Ni/SiO2-CS, which could cause rapid decrease in conversion during only 5 h TOS on the Ni/CeOx-CS catalyst. The smaller shoulder observed on Ni/SiO2-CS, suggest that the Ni edges can be partly blocked by the surrounded silica preventing carbon formation and thus extending the life of the catalyst compared to the ceria supported catalysts. 4 Conclusions We have demonstrated the effectiveness of ISCS to prepare a highly active and selective Ni/SiO2-CS and Ni-Cu/SiO2-CS catalysts with long-term stability. Similar prepared catalysts supported on ceria do not exhibit the stability of silica supported catalyst which remains active for over 30 h without any deactivation, while Ni/CeOx-CS begins deactivating rapidly due to massive carbon formation on the surface as detected by XPS and TEM. Addition of Cu to Ni on ceria did not increase its stability significantly, whereas on Ni-Cu/SiO2-CS we observed no deactivation at 100% conversion over 100 h TOS. Ex-situ and in-situ characterization of fresh and spent catalysts indicate that the significant increase in stability of the Ni/SiO2-CS catalysts can be due to Ni becoming partially encapsulated and constrained by the porous silica particles during ISCS. FTIR results suggest that the support can preferentially covers the active metal step and edges of the embedded crystallites hindering carbon formation. Addition of Cu to Ni on silica increases the number of active sites, both of which can be encapsulated by the silica support. Furthermore the formation of a surface Cu-Ni alloy could also decrease C formation on these sites resulting in a remarkable active and stable Ni-Cu/SiO2-CS catalyst. coredata.dc:description: We report on the high activity and stability towards deactivation during ethanol decomposition of mono (Ni, Cu) and bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts supported on ceria and silica that were prepared by impregnated support solution combustion synthesis (ISCS). Ni supported on ceria, behaves much like bulk Ni, as it deactivates within a few hours of time on stream (TOS). Addition of Cu improves the stability of ceria supported Ni-Cu bimetallic catalysts but it still deactivates during 10 h of TOS. Ni prepared by dry impregnation on silica deactivates completely during a few h of TOS. Ni supported on silica prepared by ISCS, show a remarkable high stability for over 30 h TOS and Ni-Cu is stable over 100 h of TOS operating at 100% conversion. XRD, XPS, HRTEM, in-situ XAS and textural characterization of these catalysts show that the surface Ni concentration is small on silica-supported catalysts due to partial encapsulation of Ni by the silica support, which protects the metal particles from carbon formation, thus hindering deactivation. Addition of Cu to silica increases the number of active sites, but also decreases CO chemisorption on Ni indicating the formation of a Cu-Ni alloy, which had been reported to inhibit carbon formation on Ni. The combined effect of encapsulation and formation of Ni-Cu surface alloys result in the remarkable stability of the Cu-Ni silica supported catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active and stable Ni-Cu supported catalysts prepared by combustion synthesis for hydrogen production from ethanol
